intro: Silene grayi, commonly known as Gray's catchfly, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Caryophyllaceae family and is characterized by its delicate, pink to purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in arid or semi-arid environments. It has hairy stems and leaves, and its fruit is a capsule that releases tiny seeds when mature. Silene grayi is often found in open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes.
